# The `OStream` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/ostream">json::OStream</a> allows writing well-formed JSON without materializing all structures as <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">json::Value</a> ahead of time. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Declaration

<CodeBlock>class llvm::json::OStream</CodeBlock>

## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/ostream">json::OStream</a> allows writing well-formed JSON without materializing all structures as <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">json::Value</a> ahead of time.

It&#39;s faster, lower-level, and less safe than OS &lt;&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">json::Value</a>. It also allows emitting more constructs, such as comments.

Only one &quot;top-level&quot; object can be written to a stream. Simplest usage involves passing lambdas (Blocks) to fill in containers:

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/ostream">json::OStream</a> J(OS); J.array(&#91;&amp;&#93;&#123; for (const Event &amp;E : Events) J.object(&#91;&amp;&#93; &#123; J.attribute(&quot;timestamp&quot;, int64&#95;t(E.Time)); J.attributeArray(&quot;participants&quot;, &#91;&amp;&#93; &#123; for (const Participant &amp;P : E.Participants) J.value(P.toString()); &#125;); &#125;); &#125;);

This would produce JSON like:

&#91; &#123; &quot;timestamp&quot;: 19287398741, &quot;participants&quot;: &#91; &quot;King Kong&quot;, &quot;Miley Cyrus&quot;, &quot;Cleopatra&quot; &#93; &#125;, ... &#93;

The lower level begin/end methods (<a href="#a5741cf7e48bbab22369fa2aa8c9e151f">arrayBegin()</a>) are more flexible but care must be taken to pair them correctly:

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/ostream">json::OStream</a> J(OS); for (const Event &amp;E : Events) &#123; J.objectBegin(); J.attribute(&quot;timestamp&quot;, int64&#95;t(E.Time)); J.attributeBegin(&quot;participants&quot;); for (const Participant &amp;P : E.Participants) J.value(P.toString()); J.attributeEnd(); J.objectEnd(); &#125; J.arrayEnd();

If the call sequence isn&#39;t valid JSON, asserts will fire in debug mode. This can be mismatched begin()/end() pairs, trying to emit attributes inside an array, and so on. With asserts disabled, this is undefined behavior.

Definition at line 979 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/json-h">JSON.h</a>.

### comment() {#a8d6140131d6891e8ca8c134b889b8ec8}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void llvm::json::OStream::comment (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">llvm::StringRef</a> Comment)</>}>
Emit a JavaScript comment associated with the next printed value.

The string must be valid until the next attribute or value is emitted. Comments are not part of standard JSON, and many parsers reject them!

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/json-h/#l01028">1028</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/json-h">JSON.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/json-cpp/#l00803">803</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/json-cpp">JSON.cpp</a>.

Emit an externally-serialized value.

The caller must write exactly one valid JSON value to the provided stream. No validation or formatting of this value occurs.
